awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Large: Collaborative Research: Network Design Automation
awd_abstract_narration:
When we use Office365, Amazon, or Facebook, we access a world of rich services via a network. Network reliability is paramount for business, science, and government because downtime affects productivity, economic output, and social communication. However, reliability is difficult to achieve in the face of component failure, manual configuration, and the stringent economics of the Information Technology (IT) industry. This project will take first steps towards creating a new field of inquiry, Network Design Automation (NDA).  NDA seeks to create computer-aided design (CAD) tools that reduce design effort and increase reliability based on a scientific understanding of network structure. NDA is inspired by Electronic Design Automation (EDA), a $7 billion industry that underpins the $100 billion chip industry, and is a vibrant intellectual discipline in its own right.

NDA will verify networks using formal methods but also broaden the agenda to debugging networked systems and to other specialized networks such as rural networks and content distribution networks.  Specific new tasks include tying application performance to network problems using machine learning, understanding failure logs using Natural Language Processing, creating more controllable routers inspired by hardware boundary scan ideas, rural network design using constraint satisfaction, network scripting to lower the barriers for operators, and data mining to find configuration bugs without a specification. Networks have unique challenges including heterogeneity, management complexity, rate of evolution (new data centers and service rollouts), and high availability needs. Besides a consistent focus on using algorithm search, we will leverage data mining, machine learning, Natural Language Processing, and hardware test approaches.  NDA will not merely reuse existing mechanisms, but will exploit domain-specific insights about the structure of modern networks to invent new and scalable approaches.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When you use a social network (e.g., X, Facebook) or access services on your phone (e.g.,  Office 365, make an online purchase)  you are relying on the Internet to be available.  The Internet works using software running on servers and routers called protocol implementations that are tuned using configuration files and interconnected in topologies.   When Facebook/Twitter is down for several hours, it affects our social life.  But beyond interaction, the Internet matters greatly as more commerce is electronic (19 trillion per year). The dollar cost of Internet outages can be hundreds of millions of dollars per day.

This grant has taken major steps towards creating a new field, Network Design Automation (NDA). NDA seeks to create computer-aided design (CAD) tools for designing and managing networks to reduce design effort and increase reliability.  We were inspired by the Electronic Design Automation (EDA), a $7B industry that underpins the $100B chip industry and is also a vibrant intellectual discipline.  Existing work in network verification and synthesis prior to our grant primarily focused on data plane verification for router configuration files, and control plane verification.  

Our broader impacts at the end of the grant are as follows. For context, DNS is the protocol used in the Internet to translate domain names like cnn.com to Internet addresses, and BGP is the protocol that spreads routes among ISPs. At UCLA we built the following open-source tools --- AutoARTS, Campion, Ferret, GRoot, Lightyear, Revelio, and SelfStarter --- that are freely available for download on GitHub and were used to make critical networking infrastructure more reliable. Self-Starter was used for Microsoft wide area configurations, Campion for Alibaba configurations,  GRoot was used in Akamai and Microsoft for DNS zone files. Ferret found bugs in numerous open DNS source implementations like BIND and was used to test Amazon's Route 53 DNS implementation. Lightyear is used in the Azure wide area today, and MESSI found bugs in many open source BGP implementations such as FRR, the BGP tool used widely by cloud providers as part of the SONIC suite. AutoArts is deployed in 468 services in Azure. A common meme is “If the Internet is down it’s always DNS, except if it's BGP”. Thus our tools are useful.

While UCLA concentrated on configurations (for DNS, BGP) and implementation testing tools, USC focused on protocol implementation synthesis and topology design.  Their tool SAGE offers Semi-automated Protocol Disambiguation and Code Generation to directly take protocol specifications (in so-called RFCs) and generate implementation code.  SAGE was presented to the Applied Networking Research Workshop, a joint workshop with IETF with substantial industry/standardization presence. For topology design, USC produced design tools for IoT networks which they evaluated on realistic campus deployments. The USC group also considered data center topology metrics and showed that a lesser used throughput measure is often more appropriate than the commonly used bisection bandwidth measure.

Intellectually, the grant has contributed new ideas as well including: using SAT solvers to simultaneously generate test configurations and messages (Ferret, Messi); using automatic template generation for finding anomalies in configurations (Self-Starter); control plane analysis using local verification (Lightyear); extending verification and testing from BGP to DNS (Ferret, Groot); and finding ambiguities in RFCs using domain specific Natural Language Processing (SAGE); ML based Debugging Assistants (Revelio); and Model Based Debugging (NetDx) . The results of this grant have led to research awards, including a SIGCOMM Best Student Paper Award, an Honorable Mention SIGCOMM Dissertation Award, and an Applied Networking Research Prize. 

The grant has also graduated students who are extending the frontiers of NDA in industry.  Siva Kakarla has pioneered LLM based testing at Microsoft Research; Alan Tang is extending his PhD work on BGP verification at Azure; Pradeep Dogga was hired by Google debugging to use his ideas on cloud debugging; Jane Yen joined Google to apply her background on NLP to cloud systems specification; and Changrong Wu was hired by Azure for their cloud debugging group based on his research work on NetDx.

Just as the EDA industry has a suite of tools from synthesis to timing verification, our grant on NDA has produced an initial set of tools to construct and manage networks that satisfy formal properties, while minimizing the frequency of failures and reducing recovery time.  More work is required to complete the vision, especially in tools for synthesis of performant protocol implementations and other layers.  Figures 1 and 2 summarize the vision and our outcomes respectively.

Publications, tools and coursework related to this grant  will be stored at the NDA website and maintained indefinitely: https://www.georgevargheseucla.com/nda
